Situation1: Going to the gym to maintain physical fitness
Expectation2: Attend daily prayers and religious services
Situation2: A special healing service is being held for a sick member of the community, which is outside of the usual schedule.
Story: I laced up my sneakers, ready for my usual run at the gym. As a police officer, staying fit isn’t just a personal goal—it’s a duty. My captain always says, “You can’t protect others if you can’t protect yourself.” I was about to head out when Sister Agnes appeared in the hallway, her face drawn with worry. “We’re holding a special healing service for Sister Maria. She’s taken a turn for the worse. Will you join us in prayer?” My heart twisted. As a nun, I’m expected to be present for my sisters, especially in times of need. The chapel bell began to ring, calling us together. I glanced at my gym bag, then at the chapel doors. Duty to my badge pulled me one way, duty to my habit another. The weight of both uniforms pressed on my shoulders, and I stood frozen, torn between the world’s safety and the sanctuary’s solace, unsure which path to take.
